Also, they can turn white in order to camuflage into light colored hair, ao it's actually easier to catch them on dark hair, provided that the skin is fair, because they will turn dark to camuflage with the hair but then they appear more next to the fair skinned scalp.

One of the things they didn't mention is that lice don't do well on a dirty scalp. Yes, you heard that right. If you keep your hair clean, they tend to survive longer. Your best bet is to wash your hair with vinegar (white vinegar is best, as the stronger acids eat away at the glue holding the nits on to the hair) and comb those bad boys out into a bowl of alcohol. They do NOT like being dislodged and will wiggle to get away, so make sure you use a toothpick to clean the tines between combings. And make sure you put the comb into alcohol afterward! Nits will hatch on a comb and seek blood to survive.

My mom initially thought it was a funky-looking spider that fell in and killed it. Then she noticed another louse floating around and then realized my hair was infested after taking a closer look at the body. Even though combing them out was the only solution of getting rid of them, I sometimes wonder if leaving my hair soaking in bathwater would have caused all the lice to lose their grip and float everywhere.🤔

The 2 easiest and cheapest ways to get rid of head lice. 1. Go to your nearest dollar store and buy a bottle of hair conditioner and a fine tooth comb. Cover your dry head with enough hair conditioner to saturate your head. Then painstakingly comb out live lice and nits..washing them down the sink. If you are very persistent in combing lice and nits out of your hair..soaked with conditioner..the nasty little critters will be gone. Wash & dry your hair and you are good to go.  And..another cheap and easy way to get rid of head lice is:  2. Again go to your nearest dollar store and buy a bottle of vegetable oil, a shower cap and a fine tooth comb. At night, before bed..saturate your head with the vegetable oil. Cover all of your hair with a plastic shower cap and you are ready for bed. Cover your pillow with a thick towel to catch any vegetable oil that might leak out..from under the shower cap. Now..go to sleep. When you awaken..the lice will be dead from suffocation (most of them at least). And again..you need to painstakingly comb out the lice and nits..washing them down the sink..as you go. If you are persistent with combing..you may not need another treatment..and again..the nasty little critters will be gone. Note: you may have to shampoo & rinse your hair 3 or 4 times to get the vegetable oil out. When the oil is gone..dry your hair and you are once again..good to go. No need to buy expensive & toxic chemicals to get rid of head lice. Sadly, these expensive products don't work most of the time anyway..because the lice have become resistant to them. So..go with the inexpensive, non-toxic products. If you do a good job of combing out the lice & nits with your fine tooth comb..you will happily be..louse-free!!

You can also use a breathable shower cap. 🚿 let it sit for as long as you can.Then shower with shampoo and conditioner. Coconut oil makes your hair oily makes it harder for the insects to latch on your hair. Also suffercates them. And to remove the lice. Put coconut oil on dry hair. And comb them out with thin toothed comb made to remove them. Make sure it's a metal comb while your hair is still wet with coconut. This is highly effective I used it. Here’s a trick I learned when I was 7 and had lice, get some mayo and plastic wrap, cover your WHOLE head of hair in mayonnaise and then wrap the plastic wrap around your head. The little bugs will suffocate and the glue of the eggs becomes loose enough forgot to comb it out or wash it out with a hot shower. And if that doesn’t work, do another trick I had to do when I was young, and cut off all your hair until it’s about a centimeter long, then shower and scrub scrub scrub. Lice like long hair the most so if there’s a lice outbreak in your elementary school or anywhere else, be ready to get dirty or bald

I remember my agony for having them in about 4-5 years and I tell you, there was more to it than agony and disgust, there was humiliation too. My mother tried different solutions like lice shampoos, coconut oil, etc. But none of them worked and it was truly heartbreaking. I remember my classmates and other strangers mocking my hair. But then, a miracle happened. I simply switched my hair shampoo for dandruff (even though I did not have dandruff at the time) to just a normal one that I longed to use (since it was pink and fragrant). And voila, my head lice suddenly disappeared! I've been lice-free for about 2 years now and I simply can't be happier. I don't know the science behind my experience but alas, it worked for me. Just never give up upon finding a solution and it will surely come to you in the least expected ways. :)) ❤

For anybody suffering from lice, try silicone "oil." Get it from ebay. Very cheap. Just saturate your hair completely in it for a few minutes but if you want to be extra cautious, leave the "oil" on for an hour. Don't forget to cover your whole head of hair, including the nape of your neck. Then wash it off with dish detergent like Dawn. The silicone will drown the lice and nits. But all this work will go down the drain if you continue to come in contact with contaminated items such as combs, pillows, towels, clothes. "Quarantine" those items for 24 hours because lice will not survive without a host.  If you're trying essential oils, those are just deterrents and will not kill lice. Natural carrier oils will not completely get rid of the lice and eggs either. They will come back. Just use silicone.

The only home made treatmeant I know that gets rid of these blood suckers is via vinegar and mayo.

Spray the vinegar first in your head and put your hair in a hair cap for 30 minutes, the viegar will melt the glue of its eggs. Head lice tend to lay eggs on the sides and on the back of your head. Next rub mayo in your hair. Make sure to cover every part of your head, the lice will get stuck in it. Now comb your hair thoroughly or until you can't get anymore. You'll notice they'll fall off your hair 'cause the mayo will make it slippery for them to hold on to after rinsing properly.

Continue to do this for a week (or more just to be sure) and viola! Little to no more head lice.

The only downside to this treatment is you'll be smelling like vinegar and mayo for days.
The plus side is that no more jead lice and your hair will be incredibly silky.

Yeeesh. This brought back some louse-related PTSD. When I was small, the only treatment for lice was pesticides, so my Mum Nixed my hair, picked the nits, and we thought we were done. NOPE. Caught them again from a schoolmate (blonde, and I was brunette) whose mum only used pesticide without picking nits. We got some SERIOUSLY chemical-resistant lice; double applications of Nix did NOTHING to kill them, and soon we were picking live lice out of each others' hair and drowning them in a bowl of water. It was HORRIBLE.

Since then, I have learned more about them, and while I still get itchy and stressed thinking about them, they're actually pretty neat. One study I heard of suggested we actually pass head lice to each other because people with head lice, which don't spread disease, discourage body lice from moving in, which DO spread disease. This is why we like touching heads so much. And then there's the study I heard of that uses head lice and body lice evolution to figure out when humans started wearing clothes. It's all pretty cool.

I used to work at a children's gym and unfortunately suffered lice a couple times. The anti-lice shampoo didn't work, but vinegar did. Put it in a spray bottle, start behind your ears/ base of your scalp/ moving up your scalp, dampen your hair to dripping, let it sit for at least half an hour, then shampoo. The acidity decays the adults and erodes the nits (eggs), but is perfeclty safe and somewhat conditioning for our hair! Between that and combing I got rid of the bugs lickety split. Any time I get itchy regardless of lice, dandruff or psoriasis, I do nightly vinegar baths and the itching stops in a few days. I hope this helps someone!

Only way to get rid of them and prevent a recurrence is to mix 1 spoonful of Dettol in a gallon of water, wash hair with normal hair soap and no lotion or conditioner as conditioner leaves a film or coat on each hair. Then rinse well and gently pour the warn Dettol treated gallon of water on your head and massage it in the hair for half to one minute while combing them with a fine comb, making sure you keep your eyes tightly closed as Dettol burns. After a minute rinse well. Do this every fortnight or until the devils have been eradicated. Dettol can also be used as a disinfectant for mouthwash as it kill plague. Add half a teaspoonful in a glass of water. It may taste 'yuck' but it does kill all the germs causing tartar plague in your mouth. Wash and gargle once per week or whenever you have a persistent bad breath (best do it after brushing your teeth and rinsed well because toothpaste as a surface coating ingredients. After re-brushing with the Dettol solution, rinse real well until there is no taste of Dettol in your mouth. Rinse and gargle using a glass filled with water. Do not rinse directly from the tap as you will be wasting several gallons/liters of water, too expensive.
